Result.Abstract: We compared psychophysiological stress recovery and directed attention restoration in natural and urban field settings using repeated measures of ambulatory blood pressure, emotion, and attention collected from 112 randomly assigned young adults. To vary restoration needs, we had half of the subjects begin the environmental treatment directly after driving to the field site. The other half completed attentionally demanding tasks
Result.Title: Tracking restoration in natural and urban field settings

Result.Abstract: Recent policy discussions about information technology in transport and traffic demand management have increased interest in activity‐based approaches to the analysis of travel behaviour, in particular in the modelling of household activity scheduling which is at the core of many of the required changes in travel behaviour. Result.Title: Activity‐based approaches to travel analysis: conceptual frameworks, models, and research problems

Result.Title: ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERN: CONCEPTUAL DEFINITIONS, MEASUREMENT METHODS, AND RESEARCH FINDINGS

Result.Abstract: The study investigates determinants of private car users' acceptance of road pricing. Result.Title: Determinants of private car users' acceptance of road pricing

Result.Title: Selective attention and heart rate responses to natural and urban environments

Result.Title: Introduction: Habitual travel choice

Result.Title: Empirical tests of a model of determinants of script-based driving choice

Result.Title: RATING SCALE MEASURES OF RESTORATIVE COMPONENTS OF ENVIRONMENTS

Result.Abstract: Business-to-business relationships are characterized by an exchange between two or more parties. Result.Title: An analysis of international business-to-business relationships based on the Commitment–Trust theory

Result.Abstract: A conceptual framework is presented that may be utilized when analyzing changes in household travel arising from the range of potential measures available to policy makers. The proposed framework draws on goal setting theory in order to understand how travel is influenced by the impact various travel demand management (TDM) measures have on time, cost, and convenience of travel options.
Result.Title: A conceptual analysis of the impact of travel demand management on private car use

Result.Title: Computational-process modelling of household activity scheduling

Result.Title: Changes in Drivers’ Perceptions and Use of Public Transport during a Freeway ClosureEffects of Temporary Structural Change on Cooperation in a Real-Life Social Dilemma

Result.Title: Application of attitude theory for improved predictive accuracy of stated preference methods in travel demand analysis

Result.Title: Frequency of negative critical incidents and satisfaction with public transport services. II

Result.Title: Moderating effects of social value orientation on determinants of proenvironmental behavior intention

Result.Abstract: An operational model of household activity scheduling is proposed. Result.Title: Computer simulation of household activity scheduling

Result.Title: Household choices of car-use reduction measures

Result.Title: Psychological determinants of attitude towards and willingness to pay for green electricity

Result.Title: Reintroducing attitude theory in travel behavior research: The validity of an interactive interview procedure to predict car use

Result.Title: The role of uncertainty in resource dilemmas

Result.Title: Euro Illusion: Psychological Insights into Price Evaluations with a Unitary Currency

Result.Title: Car-user responses to travel demand management measures: goal setting and choice of adaptation alternatives

Result.Title: A cross-country study of fairness and infringement on freedom as determinants of car owners' acceptance of road pricing

Result.Title: Development of script-based travel mode choice after forced change

Result.Title: Weighing the past and the future in decision making

Result.Title: Activity rescheduling: reasoned or habitual?
